field_paragraph_text.value:
Step 1. List every cost that you could possibly have to run your program based on the plan that you have created. List everything that you can think of, whether you can afford it or not, or whether it is important or not.

  • Costs associated with your building – rent, utilities, cleaning costs.
  • Costs associated with starting your program (what you need before you can start anything) – furniture, materials, resources.
  • Costs associated with running your program each day, week, or month – food, materials, internet.
  • Costs associated with marketing and fundraising – purchasing a website domain, maintaining a website, running an event, printing brochures, thank you cards, postage, phone calls.
  • Other costs that you will have occasionally – transportation, fees (bank, legal, etc), purchasing technology, office supplies.
  • Costs that you will have with personnel (staff and volunteers) – salaries, taxes, insurance, benefits, training, licenses.

 

Step 2. Begin categorizing them and prioritizing them. For the budget that you must give to Cultivate, and likely for future donors, you will need to create a budget that has 3 main categories: Administrative, Fundraising, and Program. All your costs must be under one of these categories. Administrative costs are what is required to keep your project running but are not directly related to your program – things such as office supplies, utilities, and internet. Fundraising costs are what is required so that you can receive donations – costs such as creating marketing brochures that you give to potential donors, the costs of an event, or the costs for receiving donations such as credit card processing fees (which usually are 3.5%). Program costs is everything that is directly associated with your program – your staff, your materials, etc. Take all your costs and list them in order of priority – what do you absolutely need to have and what is less needed. Create a list for each category and put the items in order from most important to least important.

Administrative Costs

  1. Most important

….

10.       Least important.

Fundraising Costs

  1. Most important

….

10.        Least important.

Program Costs

  1. Most important

….

10.        Least important.

 

Step 3. Find out the actual costs for those items. Make sure you find out if costs will change in the coming months, if there are extra fees to anything, and when you will be expected to pay.

If you are starting a project, one cost that you will need to determine is a salary either for yourself or other staff. In order for your project to be approved by Cultivate, your salaries will need to be appropriate for your community. Costs vary greatly from one country or community to another, so you will need to do good research to find out how much someone should get paid in your community for the responsibilities that they have. You will need to explain in your project proposal how you determined what an appropriate salary is for your project. Our goal is that all of your staff, including you, are given a salary that honors their work, the level of responsibility that they have in their job, and allows them to live in a way that they have sufficient food, a safe home, their children can be educated, and they have sufficient money for things such as medical costs (this is called a livable salary). What you may consider to be a livable salary may be completely different than what someone else in your community considers livable. This is going to be a difficult thing to determine, and it may take years until you are able to raise enough money to reach this level, but we ask that you and your team dedicate yourselves to eventually offering your staff a livable salary.

 

Step 4. Decide what you will put into your final budget. Work with your team and take the time to decide what costs are absolutely important and what you should take out. This may be a very difficult process. If you are just starting your program, it may be difficult to decide what is most important and what you should keep or take out. If you already have a program that has been running for a while, you will have a better understanding of what your costs are and what is a priority. Remember, your budget is simply a plan to help you. You may create a budget for your program that is $5,000 for the year, but the reality is that you may only receive $1,000 in donations. You will only be able to spend the money that you have and will need to make changes to your project to fit the money that you have received.

 

Step 5. Create an expense budget. You will need to create a budget based on your costs for an entire year, but if it is easier for you, you can first create a weekly or monthly budget.  Put your costs into each appropriate section.
